header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends
header.topics: The Great British Sewing Bee BBC tv programme, Mum’s sewing, Clothes Mum made for Sue in the 60s and 70s, 60s haircuts, Car parking in central London
header.activity: Chatting with sister, late Tuesday evening

body.u: so are yo are you enjoying this series of the Sewing Bee?

erm yes in large part it's it's quite good entertainment but the some of the erm sewing is a bit er strange cos there's no kind of emphasis on the under finishing or anything like that cos it's just make it in the time
yes which is you know fair enough they haven't got long but
but some of them do seem a little on the ragged side and they do seem to use patterns
you kn they do seem to follow a pattern rather than some of them'll modify patterns but er
I think this time I think in prev I think previously they had a direct make or something as a on a particular week
well they had to fit it directly on the person or they had to make a paper pattern I can't quite remember
but there was something but there is one part I mean generally there's one part where they have to they're given a pattern and they have to make it up
which is reasonable isn't it? cos that's ssort of like a blind challenge

well it yes I mean they have been choosing their own patterns but and they had patterns for jackets and things but er you know some of the more simple stuff I suppose the er what do you call it? the revamping things
the alteration challenge is a bit erm a bit different on that but er
they're sort of making something out of a pattern then aren't they? although some people make their own paper one
but they tend to be a bit a lot of those tend to be more loose garments don't they?
and they can be a bit thrown together
and sometimes they don't always seem to have the use the material that appropriately I don't think like
I think mum would have a few things to say about it cos they have a big piece of material
and they just pin things all over the place on it
and er mum was very good wasn't she about erm
oh yes well mum was a
er making sure it went together as s in small er small as small a space as possible?
but then it does depend on the pattern a bit doesn't it?
the patt your repeat like on

well it does to some extent on the other hand what I haven't seen them doing particularly is opening the material out erm and refolding it in a different way because mum used to refold her material so that you could get well you know one leg up one way and one leg up the other not put two legs following or something
you know so you would use
so instead of getting a wasted bit in the middle
if you well you had to put it against well no if you had to put it against the the er fold er against if you folded it in half to do it double to get the symmetrical shape
well mum wouldn't fold it like they sort of seem to fold it in half and cut it against the fold so
you get a big scrap along the bottom

of the the selvedge er there whereas mum would only fold it as far down as she needed to cut the size so she'd then have an extra piece of material that was double the size of the scrap they're getting
and you could then put another piece in it so you could cut possibly one bit and then from the bit that was left over that wasn't folded
she could cut the other bit flat you know refold it down the middle and

cut out the one the other way by erm moving it up or moving it down slightly cos I remember at school when we used to get s erm told well we used to have to follow a pattern like the pyjamas we made stripy pyjamas I think I did get the material from school in that case but for example with similar things like that
the pattern a proper shop-bought pattern would say you need two yards
erm mum would say you don't need t we we don't need to do it in two yards we can do it in
a yard and a half or whatever it was and er we had to buy the patterns as well so mum used to pin the pattern on the material
or show me where to pin it on the material
erm and I'd take it to school like that and then at school I would put it on more carefully you know she wasn't doing it all for me but she would show so I could show the teacher where the bits went
but you didn't actually need that extra half a yard
especially if you were buying some you know reasonably expensive material
and anyway it saves the pennies and that was important
and that was important but you see mum I mean mum was a tailoress really I know she did dressmaking but high standards cos she did make suits and well she made everything from the skin skin upwards
outwards erm really cos in those in those days erm during during the war and aft after I mean they they made underwear and everything from
if they could get a bit of parachute silk

they'd use that for underwear and ladies would go and buy a full matching set of something you know so they'd have the the slip and the knickers and everything and then they'd erm you know they would buy erm sort of an outfit

sso mum could do all that and she could do I mean she that's what I mean she did tailoring in those days they had quite fitted jackets and things she could do tailoring and erm so on and being wartime those men's-wise baggy trousers they used to have
on suits if you got an old pair of trousers you could make a a decent skirt out of it cos you've got
to play about with so you could cut it in a would it be a ? you'd certainly make a panelled a six-panelled skirt or

erm any of those sort of ones that you need seams in so erm she was dab hand at doing that from little bits of material and of course my friend was in her element when she was er came round because she loved sewing
so mum and her would be patterning and looking at this that and the other sorting things out
er not really I don't think they actually made anything together but they talked about what they were doing
I don't think she actually helped with anything and was pretty good at doing things so made a suede coat cos her father had got these erm skins
from somewhere or other and erm made a suede coat when they were fashionable in the sixties
you know with the covered buttons and everything and it looked perfectly decent which is quite a a lot for a sort of sixteen-year-old or so
although one of those on the telly is sixt
yes she's not old is she?
I think her name might be Jade
I don't think she's particularly old
and she was saying the best thing she'd made was her prom dress
well I think she's yes she's a later sort of
teenager I think as well but you know was quite sort of confident about
cutting this erm expensive stuff up and well sh you know you she used to run up things to wear at the dance
or same as mum did for me cos I used to draw it and she used to make it
did you see things in magazines or shops? how did you get your ideas? or did you just do them you did you kind of know what people had and make one up?
well I kind of saw bits of things I liked and made one up really
erm cos I kn I well it's the same as now I never actually want to actually be wearing what everybody else is wearing
well you certainly don't do that

you know er I wouldn't just want to be looking like everybody else but I like to take the kind of the the theme and erm m plus mum had provisos cos was wha I was only er like I wasn't allowed to down to the dance till I was seventeen I think it as yes and er mum had provisos as to what I could actually have so as to how low the front was and you know well not how how shshort the skirt was to some extent although they were shorter skirts so erm you know there was that to consider so I did have some quite a few dresses that had quite er a low neckline at the back you know
up to up to your bra strap which was quite erm daring
would you d you covered up in those days

yes which you didn't go you ddefinitely did didn't show your straps like they do now and if you've got a if you've got a sleeveless dress you would have little er little poppers and loops to put under your bra to keep it
mm mm I was looking at one er out of my summer clothing and wondering if I'd sewn that kind of arrangement in because it's always a bit awkward
when I or whether it came and I couldn't couldn't decide
no or or you would use erm a very little tiny gold pins
erm as well they were useful and if you had a halterneck dress then you'd you'd have a a suitably shaped bra strap
yes you wouldn't wear over-the-shoulder straps
which people do now like that lady I was talking ttelling you about on the train
who had this sort of quite it was a sort of the first hot it was the hotte I should think it was the hottest day of the year
so far and she had this sort of vesty top and this sort of padded erm foamy sort of big cup bra
well I don't know do they push up? I'm not sure what a Wonderbra does but
I I think it's supposed to enhance one's potential
but it ththere's some that really look as though they're made of bits of erm foamy material that is sort of
that sort of really er anyway it there was quite a l I could I could I could check it out quite carefully
because of the way her her top wwent
I can remember you had some er some of your dresses did you have a lot of pinky a silky-looking one? I don't think it was silky
I think it was a new fabric
it was it was it was erm it could have been Tricel

and it it was a sort of apricot I suppose a pale apricot colour and that had a bit of sheen to it and was erm it was a fitted bodice it was sleeveless with a small er with a square neck but not too low

it had a square neck er it was sleeveless and it came in under the it was fitted under the bust with a tiny band and that bodice was all erm it was ruched up it was lines of sewing and then pinched in to gather so it was all little ruches all the way over
and it had the same binding on the erm edge of the sleeves and round
and round the neck and it was square neck and the back and then it had a sort of A-line skirt not gathered or anything it was just an A-line as was per sixties
and it was just a bit above the knee
are you thinking of a plain one or one with a swirly pattern on?
no I'm thinking of a plain one but
the material had got a slightly erm kind of embossed it wasn't shin it wasn't so shiny it did have a slight textured embossed tiny little
sq er think on it and I also because I had my short short hair with a backcombed bit I used to have a little bow I had a little bl bow on a clip
I always think of that being a a sort of a a kind of peachy orange actually
well it yes it wasn't sort of loud the loud one
I had which you probably liked was the one with the swirly different colours it that was pinky purplely
white er swirly things cos it was like psychedelic I'm
I was meant I was talking about
I thought the small-scale it's er small-scale swirls
and it was all sort of like it was was on the psychedelic era
with little white and grey and
swirly things it sounds horrendous but er and that had that again was sleeveless erm with just a plain-faced sleeve er underneath er er armhole underneath and it had a V-neck
iit had a V-neck with a collar on it like a

a flat nnot standing up like a shirt collar but like a flat a quite a small collar roll collar at the back but the ends of it were slightly er a little bit pointy not the the every so long points you sometimes got

and then that was erm had erm darts and darts from the waist so the bodice was fitted erm and it had a it was waisted and it had erm I think it it wasn't it had a slightly flared skirt because it that again was erm was it it wasn't it might have been Tricel there was another word for er it was a man-made fibre but it didn't screw up or anything it was and it was thin
it was very fine like a silky fine thin material
er and it had a belt on it with a little buckle and the little pinky erm oblong curved it was it sort of it it was an oblong shape but it had a curve to it
so it fitted against your waist and that was an old one of mum's from
I don't know nineteen thirties or something that er went round it and that was quite quite short
and again I had a I think I had a ribbon that time I had a erm ribbony thing that I could do into a bow in the same material and it was it was very bright but it was very nice
and you had one with a another belted one
and of course having said that it ha it did have a little pocket in it as well cos
mother always tried to put a pocket in somewhere yes
and there was one for your cloakroom ticket
well well one would have one's handbag but
oh and you had another one with a belt didn't you? er it had more sort of erm if it seemed a bit more like a shirt
a purple purple and yellow and
no oh n are you thinking of the swirly one?
not not the pink swirly one no erm
I can't think which one that was
but another one you had was like erm you had made nighties out of that erm slightly furry fabric
er you know like like the yyyou've got that apricot long nightie
well it had little stripes across
brushed nylon is that what you call it?
it was like a big T-shirt with those pearl buttons on it
oh I know what you mean yes yes
and they had lots of different colours
er yes that was a slightly velvety effect
was that brushed nylon or am I rude about it?

with a printed erm well it's kind of like that but it was had a slightly erm velvety but it it was a kind of stretchy material and it was like a erm a big T-shirt only not like they wear now that's flappy with the off the shoulder it was erm a properly fitted your size erm s er like the top of a T-shirt erm but it had erm an oval sort of neck and it had a little placket with buttons I think at the front or
and then erm it went carried on but it was quite narrow it wasn't a flappy T-shirt it was quite fitted on the hips narrow and short and it had got a sort of wavy a wavy pattern
it wasn't a swirly one it was a wavy pattern
and it was green and orange and yellow and but it was very thin
lines it was very pretty and it it was quite a a clingy
type thing and then I of course the fashion came in cos those were kind of oh s I'm talking sixty-seven sixty-eight kind of era and then erm also knitted dresses the well crocheted

ddresses erm but you could also have a knitted dress with a holey pattern in a crocheted pattern in and it wasn't too holey and erm it had scallop crochet round the end and it was just like a erm I suppose like a a shift you know it was just erm it was just like a a vesty top only with a higher boat neck slightly cut in erm armholes and erm straight and thin erm just and it had scalloping round the edges and it was like erm not navy-blue a sor a warmer colour than that sort of midnight blue and of course it was very holey you're supposed to have tassels round the bottom but I never got the tassels and I had scallops instead and there was a twisted wool belt thing
and you tie round but it was it was a bit holey so mum made a lining for it
so I had a lined one cos she didn't
think it was quite the thing

to go round showing your holes through the skin through the holes so erm I had this lining which was it was lining material and it was very sort of erm er it was a what would you call it? erm I can't think of the name it was like a satin it got a sheen on it it was the same colour
as the dress but got a bit of a sheen so
when the light caught it it was quite
pretty in the holes and it also kept the shape of the dress better cos some people's some people's crocheted dresses tended to sort of grow with them or
get longer and things bit like possibly a bit like knitted swimming costumes of the early fifties
I think you did well not to have the tassels I think they're much overrated
I'm not sure tassels would have looked very nice on it I think scallop was
I always fancied one of those dresses that had that has erm possibly three or four inch er fringe that layers of fringe
somebody made one on one of the Sewing Bees I think didn't they?
so so it shakes about and you don't have to move much although I used to move quite a lot but you know
erm yes and and then what else do you remember? do you remember my camel and green?
more a day dress wasn't it?
yes camel and green was camel and green was erm one of mother's creations thinking of erm er challenges for alterations I think I think the camel started off was going to be a pair of camel trousers
because they were the thing at the time
er cos this would have been er when did I go to college? this would have been late sixties erm and it was if of the era of the two-tone

er so I thought I'd have this winter erm camel trousers but I don't know they didn't seem to be right so mum took them apart I mean she'd made them sort of very well but they just didn't seem to look right on me
erm she'd fitted them you know when once they were
pantomime horse trousers didn't you later on?
well this is it yes they were they were corduroy trousers that looked like the back of a pantomime horse even though I wasn't quite that broad across the beam anyway er mum
I think that was part of the problem actually

yes mum er we had this pair of trousers and they must have been reasonably straight trousers er and mum made this panelled dress for me it was military-style and it had bottle green s long sleeves in fine wool erm er quite a fitted sleeve and it had a a yoke that was erm that had two points down along the front
so it looked kind of a bit like a back of a military jacket front and back

so that was a bottle green and then the rest of it was these trousers so where the point of the bodice came the yoke came there was a an over-sewn seam down each side and and at the back which also did the fitting for the front
because you only needed narrow panels
and because it was a shorter dress you could get it out of the trouser length
erm so that was my camel and green and I wore it for my college interview
oh and very appropriate for a
and erm as I say erm I think not so long back mentioned the camel and green cos you know as a creation it had a long zip down the back

that was one of mum's things and then I had erm there was that very nice it was a long dress was it? I think it was a long dress originally the one in the little pattern that your work bag your er sewing bag is lined in
that was a pretty one but
well we all had those long skirts didn't we?
yes well this was a dress with a erm a square sort of piece and it had not lace round it
a square erm bit on the front erm yoke sort of erm a square thing and slightly puffed sleeves and long sleeves erm cuffs long cuffs long sleeves and it had grandma's lace round it
that lace was nanny 's lace just a tiny bit let in cos it was the same colour as that was a Laura Ashley-type fabric
little showery things and then mum shortened that for me I think

I don't remember it other than that

I don't remember having a red skirt

yes can't remember what one that was now

with erm buttons on because yours
was quite subtle and mine was rather bright
I'm not sure I really liked it but erm
I think mine was a slightly darker navy

oh and I remember in earlier days well earlier days probably sixty-seven erm in the era of erm hiphipster skirts I had that sort of wasn't purple it was more a dark violet coloured one with a wide belt and it ha it had father's army ex-army sur you know doing his military service wartime brass belt that I had
on the front and that was very short
and it was before tights came in
so and you had erm they were like erm erm lacy sort of openwork erm creamy colour was very popular
and you had the creamy colour
stockings and the shorter skirt which took some manoeuvring and then I had a creamy t colour sort of slightly openwork jumper I used to wear

you know and then and it was the era of the pale lipstick as well the mascara and the pale lipstick and the backcombed hair yes I remember wearing that the trouble is some of these little skirts and I thought oh that's quite nice material and I couldn't get into them some years later and I unpicked them cos I thought they might nice material
which I didn't which is a shame because erm you know these things come round again and there was very some very nice erm like pl
you still might not fit into them

the the knitted erm with some sort of little erm detail on it that erm went with one of the colours so it was

that would be really more a Mondrian wouldn't it?
